spanishExample: Ahora ustedes se hacen buenos amigos.
englishTranslation: Now you all are becoming good friends.
vocabIncluded: hacerse: any use of Hacer with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become"
ustedes: "you" plural, subject pronoun (3rd-person plural treatment)

spanishExample: Le *I showed* eso al hombre.
englishTranslation: I showed the man that.
vocabIncluded: al: "to the" before a masculine noun
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Le va a hacer algo a su amigo.
englishTranslation: She is going to make her friend something.
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Les *I told* a mis amigos que tenía que irme.
englishTranslation: I told my friends that I had to leave.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"
les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Les *you told* eso a los chicos.
englishTranslation: You told the boys that.
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")

spanishExample: No me las *gave.*
englishTranslation: He didn’t give me them(f).
vocabIncluded: las: "them" as a direct object for feminine people/things
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: Nos la hacía.
englishTranslation: He was making it(f) for us.
vocabIncluded: hacía: "was doing/making", "he/she/it was doing/making" (Hacer, imperfect, 3rd person)
nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")

spanishExample: Nos lo va a hacer ese día.
englishTranslation: He is going to make us it(m) that day.
vocabIncluded: nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Se la *she gave* a su *son* al irse.
englishTranslation: She gave it (f) to her son upon leaving.
vocabIncluded: "se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica

spanishExample: Se las *I gave* a mis amigas.
englishTranslation: I gave them(f) to my friends(f).
vocabIncluded: "se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
las: "them" as a direct object for feminine people/things

spanishExample: Se lo *I gave* esta tarde a mis amigos.
englishTranslation: I gave it (m) to my friends(m) this afternoon.
vocabIncluded: "se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica

spanishExample: *She hopes* que se los haga a mi amigo.
englishTranslation: She hopes that I make them(m) for my friend(m).
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
"se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica

spanishExample: Si haces eso, nosotros no lo haremos.
englishTranslation: If you make that, we won’t make it.
vocabIncluded: haremos: "will do/make", "we will do/make" (Hacer, future, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Te *I told* que me lo *he gave.*
englishTranslation: I told you he gave me it(m).
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Te la haré ese año.
englishTranslation: I will make it(f) for you that year.
vocabIncluded: haré: "will do/make", "I will do/make" (Hacer, future, 1st person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Te lo *I told* ese día.
englishTranslation: I told you it(m) that day.
vocabIncluded: te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Ya te las *I gave.*
englishTranslation: I already gave them(f) to you.
vocabIncluded: las: "them" as a direct object for feminine people/things
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")
ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things

spanishExample: *They* nos la *gave.*
englishTranslation: They gave it(f) to us.
vocabIncluded: nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")

spanishExample: ¿Me los *are you giving?*
englishTranslation: Are you giving me them(m)?
vocabIncluded: me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: Le *I’m asking a question.*
englishTranslation: I’m asking her a question.
vocabIncluded: le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: *They* nos lo *told.*
englishTranslation: They told it(m) to us.
vocabIncluded: nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")
